+1 to the comments, although it would be good if we could come up with a name that is more descriptive than `Default` which states nothing about what the transform is actually doing. Maybe `ElementToString` or something like that?

--none--

Sorry for the delay!

Found the culprit: TypeToken is not serializable when we specify a variable type (so when we use the where method). What that means is that for coders needing this information (like CollectionCoder) we can not keep an instance of the TypeDescriptor: we need to create a new instance each time the method is called with the sub coders or the serialization of the coder fails.

`Default` makes sense to me in the sense that `toString` method is a default string conversion method in Java and would works for all types.

I would have preferred `create` and used it for kv and iterables too but type erasure wouldn't allow it. So I am leaning towards:
`ToString.default(), ToString.kv(String delimiter), ToString.iterable(String delimiter) and so on...`

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/6338/
--none--
Except that `default` is a keyword in Java8. So `ToString(), ToString.kv(String delimiter), ToString.iterable(String delimiter) and so on...` instead?

I don't think we can do `ToString()`, so maybe:

`ToString.element()` (calls toString on each element)
`ToString.kv(String fmt)` (for generality, may be better to take a format string rather than a delimiter)
`ToString.iterable(String delimiter)`
Done

Your comment is about the use case of an individual in their development cycle, but this PR is about Jenkins postcommit `RunnableOnService` integration tests, which often create multi-hour Jenkins queues.

We can (and should) eliminate the queue by adding build workers, but we can do even better than that.

Perhaps you extrapolated that I was trying to generally engineer our configs to make it easy - or at least possible - to quickly and hermetically build just what is needed. I also want to do that, but I don't actually know how yet, or whether it is even possible.

As I mentioned, this is just for discussion. I don't like the approach, either, but I don't know of another way that plays nice with mvn and Jenkins plugin, etc. I was hoping to prompt thoughts like yours on other ways we might address the problems here 🎺. Any other ideas?
I think a wildcard is the only way to do this.
No -- Jenkins could do the same what an engineer could do locally. In fact, Travis is engineered to specifically separate build and test phases, and we could apply the same thing to Jenkins.
R: @aaltay

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/6351/

OK, sounds like a good idea. I'll close this assuming that will be the approach taken. Certainly still quite bad in terms of simplicity and hermeticity, but better than status quo.

This is an effort to stabilize `Read.Unbounded` in the Spark runner.
- Put an end to serialization issues on read/checkpointing.
- Resolve [`BEAM-979`](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-979).
- Give stable ground to start working on [`BEAM-848`](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-848). 

R: @jbonofre

I think the point you've raised is indeed a concern. 
I would love to see if we can make use of this Graphite server-wannabe in integration tests in a wider scope, hopefully the recent move to the new metrics API will facilitate this.

The CSV sink is of a slightly different nature in the sense that it does not have a server backend like Graphite, so asserting over metrics sent from multiple (in-memory) executors to a CSV file might not be that useful.

Basically this leaves us with the question of whether we want to get this in now, or stash it till things get clearer in the metrics department. @amitsela @jbonofre ?

@amitsela 

You're right, `RDD` instances are serialized using the `Closure` serializer, which, as mentioned above uses Java serialization. For example see [here](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/v1.6.3/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/ResultTask.scala#L60)

Accumulator updates as well as seen [here](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/v1.6.3/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/TaskResult.scala#L57)

Changed the commit to reflect this, now only registering `MicrobatchSource` to serialize using Java.

R: @robertwb
Perhaps `.of()` is the better name. I think that's the most API consistent name.

Over the life of the code, we've actually had many discussions about this very issue of `serialVersionUID` and determined that it should only be set if the class meets the following:

 - Really has a format defined, preferably explicitly, and preferably backwards/forwards compatible as possible. Basically overriding Java serialization with Avro, Protobuf, Thrift, or similar.
 - Is intended to be communicated between different versions of the code, either via network or storage. In this case also the serialized form should be something other than Java serialization.

Thus, there are very few cases where the warning is helpful, so we disable it globally. I recommend disabling it and not adding this boilerplate.

The other changes Look Good To Me.
LGTM.
@yk5 Yes, that is correct. Thank you for the update.
